reviewText: SPOILER WARNING"Zontar: The Thing from Venus" is a remake of "It Conquered the World". I know that "Zontar" is an extreme low-budget production with turkey status, but I admit I somehow liked this story! With the exception of the embarrassing monster and its "injectors", of course. They give a new meaning to the expression "bats in the belfry". Otherwise, I think director Larry Buchanan solved the budget problems relatively well, by making the film look like a theatre play.The plot revolves around a mad scientist, one Tom Anderson, who is a kind of misunderstood genius. Anderson manages to contact an alien intelligence through a radio device in his own house. Of course, nobody believes him. Then, funny things start to happen: communications satellites disappear, cars and trains stop going, martial law is declared...It turns out that Anderson has struck a deal with one of the aliens, named Zontar. The alien, who has managed to reach Earth and lives in a cave, promises to solve all the world's problems. The catch: all of humanity must be "controlled" or brain-washed by the alien. By loosing all their emotions, humans will finally manage to overcome war, conflict and petty strife. The aliens are really a kind of parasites, forced to leave Venus when their former host creatures died. Humans will presumably be their new hosts, but in return, we'll get Paradise. That's very hard to believe, and it's pretty obvious that Zontar contacted Anderson in order to use his latent megalomania and misanthropy against the rest of the human race.Unfortunately for Anderson, neither his wife nor his best friend wants to accept the Neuordnung. The new utopia quickly turns into a nightmare. Eventually, Anderson realizes his mistake as Zontar (who looks like a monster bat) kills the scientist's wife in a stand off. In the finale, a somewhat wiser Anderson takes on the alien with a sophisticated laser device, killing both Zontar and himself. The narrator then recites a new agey message about change being a thing that must come from within...An interesting story! It could have been a great movie (or a theatre play) with somewhat better actors, a larger budget and a more convincing alien. I admit I resonated with the philosophical message, but I also felt a certain amount of sympathy for poor Mr. Anderson, even during his crazy phase. As a teenager, I actually wrote an (unpublished) short story on a similar theme - aliens "help" a humanity that can't improve itself - and I even considered writing a story about a bizarre political movement that wants to save the world by abolishing emotions... Old concepts within scyfy, it seems. I admit that I felt, in a somewhat megalomaniac manner, that "Zontar" was in some sense "my" story. So hey, cut the crap about this being a turkey, will ya!Obviously, I have to give "Zontar: The Thing from Venus" five stars.
summary: OK, what's so bad about this film, then?
Title: N/A

reviewText: Dr. Curt Taylor (John Agar) refused to believe there is life, malevolent or benevolent, out there. Mean while brilliant and misunderstood scientist Keith Ritchie (Anthony Houston) invite his Venus buddy Zoltar over to earth to make a few social adjustments.The philosophical discussions take precedence over the sci-fi action. And the wives (Patricia De Laney and Susan Bjurman) turn out to have a strong influence on the direction of the story.This is a TV remake of Roger Corman's low budget "It Conquered the World"The original film "It Conquered the World" with Peter Graves had the alien looking like a rubber creature with tentacles for tootsies. And instead of flying lobsters they used bat like creatures. This film even though a cheap remake seemed to spend more time on significant dialog, making it more relevant to our life.After watching these two versions of the story, be sure to watch the spoof "Lobsterman from Mars" with Tony Curtis.It Conquered the World B&W;It Conquered the World (1956) 11" x 17" Poster
summary: "It must come from the very hart of man himself."

reviewText: Zontar - Thing From Venus (sometimes known as Zontar - Invader From Venus) is a perfectly forgettable, extremely low-budget science fiction film from the 1960s.  It is actually a horribly inferior remake of It Conquered the World, brought to life by Larry Buchanan, a director whose rap sheet of horrible remakes should have been enough to get his face slapped on post office walls all over the country.  Zontar is, obviously, a Thing from Venus.  This horribly made-up excuse of a slimy, cheap-looking alien actually has made a friend on Earth, a scientist by the name of Keith.  Keith is a weird, exceedingly bland intellectual whose ideas have never been accepted by those around him; somehow he has retained a job working for his best friend Curt Taylor at some type of military rocket launching facility.  Keith tries to stop Taylor from launching the new secret laser satellite, arguing that aliens will destroy it and possibly the earth.  When the launch takes place, though, Keith changes his tune and begins preaching about a Venusian called Zontar coming to solve all of the earth's problems.  A quick hijacking of the laser satellite finds Zontar on earth, sending out pods in the form of silly, flying reptilian little buggers while Keith gives him the information he needs to control the area and eventually the world.  Zontar somehow eliminates all power sources on the planet and begins taking over the minds of important leaders.  It looks like it's up to Curt and/or Keith's wife to save the world as we know it.  It's too bad neither of them could save us, the audience, from the evils of stiff as a board acting, embarrassing special effects, and a ridiculous plot.  I would say there is definitely an anti-communist aspect to the story.  Keith is all bug-eyed and bushy-tailed over the prospects of peace and brotherhood and happiness promised by good old Zontar, but building a population of alien-controlled, unemotional shells of humanity isn't all it's cracked up to be.  Naturally, there is humor to be gained from the gross ineptitude of this film, but that's about it.
summary: Bad actors are from Earth, Zontar is from Venus
Title: N/A

reviewText: In the sixties, Dallas filmmaker Larry Buchanan made a series of extremely low-budget remakes of already low-budget AIP movies of the fifties, as a TV package.  ZONTAR is Buchanan's remake of IT CONQUERED THE WORLD.  A outcast  scientist communicates with the title character, guiding it to Earth so  that it can take over - the poor deluded guy thinks Zontar will guide  mankind to a new golden age.  Fortunately, an especially angry John Agar  (at a low ebb in his career) is there with his pistol to set things right.  Enjoyable in a train-wreck sort of way - you can be pretty sure almost all  the budget went to Agar's paycheck, leaving almost nothing for the monster.
Title: N/A

reviewerName: Lonnie E. Holder "The Review's the Thing"
reviewText: Sometimes B-science fiction movies transcended themselves to achieve something higher or greater than that to which they inspired.  Yes, greatness is sometimes inadvertent.  But, when a cast, a story, and passing special effects come together, the effect can be a timeless classic.  Of course, what I am describing is not this movie.Keith Ritchie (Tony Huston) has become radio pals with Zontar, a friendly creature from Venus.  Zontar has made Ritchie, who just reeks of geek, all sorts of promises about how great the world will become under his benevolent rule.  Ritchie, who has a nagging, whiny wife named Martha (Susan Bjurman), is a skinny guy who looks like those old advertisements about the 98 pound weakling.  But, by golly, Keith will show everyone that he has the power, courtesy of Zontar.Zontar comes to earth by stealing a satellite to make his landing.  The satellite looks suspiciously like a ball with a ring around it, but hey, it's a cheesy movie, so some allowances need to be made.  I did wonder how Zontar made it all the way from Venus to earth orbit to steal the satellite, but I guess that is just another of those mysteries of science.Once on earth, Zontar busily makes little bat-like flying critters that bite you on the neck and then make you their slave (seems like I have heard this somewhere before).  Everything would be fine except Keith wants Dr. Curt Taylor (John Agar) to join him and Zontar in making the earth a wonderful place to live, and Dr. Taylor unreasonably wants things to stay more or less as they are.  For some reason Dr. Taylor has a problem with being a slave to a creature that looks slimy and hides in a cave.If you watch this movie with an open mind it becomes quite humorous.  I enjoyed watching people running about mindlessly for no apparent reason.  I also enjoyed sirens going off when the power was supposedly completely out.  There is also at least one scene where cars are supposedly unable to run, but you see cars passing by in the distance through the trees.  Another thing that was puzzling was how Keith managed to pass by a group of soldiers outside Zontar's cave without encountering the soldiers; just one of those mysteries of life.Speaking of soldiers, early in this movie a general enslaved by Zontar sets a group of soldiers to walking about in the woods to look for suspicious activity.  I see the point of sending the soldiers off to wander about aimlessly, but what is the point of returning to them several times in the movie?  The soldiers never actually do anything, until they encounter Zontar and run for the hills, or back to the woods, or whatever.Another bit of fun is the cheesy "laser" effect when Keith wields his "plutonium ruby crystal laser."  Luke Skywalker eat your heart out!On thing that did surprise me is the amount of death in this movie.  I expect the slimy alien from Venus to kill somebody because that it what slimy Venusian monsters do.  What I didn't expect is how many people got shot or strangled.  I guess it is hard to have a slimy Venusian who struggles to walk to chase down humans and kill them, so the extra killing spiced up the movie.As silly as this movie is, it is actually interesting to watch (but you really have to like cheesy science fiction movies).  Once you have seen this one, try watching "It Conquered the World," which is better than this movie and is about a similar creature.

reviewText: You should watch this to see what can be done on ultra low budgets. The acting is so-so, aliens and tech sets look like Japanese sci-fi imports. It's fun and John Agar is in it. Just don't ask your wife/GF/significant female other to watch...my wife, daughter and friend all hated it. The guys say it's OK

reviewText: This is one of my favorite cheesy sci-fi movies from the 1960s. It was made by Larry Buchanan in 1966 as a remake of "It Conquered The World", which is itself an enjoyable bit of B-Grade cinema. By all estimates the remake is horribly inferior to the original, but "Zontar" makes up for in silliness and bogus science what it lacks in quality production values. The most notable difference between "Zontar" and "It Conquered The World" is the monster. Zontar looks like a three-eyed, hooded Sleestak with pincher jaws, whereas the original monster looked like an enraged carrot.The story concerns Keith, a brilliant lunatic scientist (Tony Huston) who conspires to bring Zontar from his home planet to help the people of Earth become more peaceful. His friend, Curt (the always gentlemanly John Agar) thinks he is nuts and eventually convinces him that he must destroy Zontar, who has taken up residence in a local cave because "it is close to his Venus environment". (Sure.) Zontar attempts to take over the world by launching "injectapods" at people which fly to their victims and implant a pin in their neck making them a biological sub-unit of Zontar. (Following all this?) I love watching the injectapods fly, and you will too when you watch this movie.After much bloodshed and panic in the streets (sample exchange after the power has gone out: "My husband's in an iron lung, what shall I do?"...now that's dialogue you don't see in just any film), Keith finally dispatches Zontar with a "Plutonium-Ruby Crystal Beam Gun" which involves the funniest special effect I have ever seen on film. The movie concludes with a real Ed Wood moment of solemn pondering about the future of mankind.In a nutshell, this is a great piece of cheese. Sure it's silly, Sure it is ludicrous watching Keith speak to Zontar via some radio gear that just goes "Bwuwuwuwuwuwuwuwuwu" over an over. But if you are looking for an excellent piece of mid 1960s paranoid sci-fi lunacy, "Zontar: The Thing From Venus" would be tough to beat!
